column2: In 1143 the people of Rome rose up, and attempted to create a new Republic of Rome, called the Commune of Rome. They set up a senate and elected Giordano Pierloni as their patrician. It was at the height of the struggle between the Guelphs and Ghibellines, so the Commune sought the protection of the Holy Roman Emperor in their war against the Pope, whom they wanted to live as a priest. The rebels controlled much of the Roman countryside, and even destroyed the Pope's refuge of Tusculum. Pope Lucius II himself was killed during the assault. Eventually the Emperor turned against them, and re-installed the Pope, but for a brief moment, Rome was a republic once more.

We have triumphed against the Pope and his allies, we are now recognized by everyone as the true successor state of The Roman Empire. Now it is in our power to decide, as a gesture of good will, to offer the Pope the Bishopric of Saint Peter and to join our glorious nation as the most prestigious of our vassals.
Try to convince The Pope to explain his disagreement.

[Prev.GetFOA] [Prev.GetTitledFirstName] I am here to ask to you to explain your differences. I have decided to grant to you the Bishopric of Saint Peter and to offer you to join the [From.PrimaryTitle.GetFullName] as the most prestigious vassal of our vassals. If you decide to accept you will obtain the title of Senator of the [From.PrimaryTitle.GetFullName]\n\nWhat do you decide to do?
This treaty is injurious! I will never sign this!

To the glorious[Prev.GetFOA] [Prev.GetTitledFirstName] I shall sign the Treaty of Lateran and I'm now ready to serve you.
I hope that together we can forge a new  "Roman Empire".

Your vassal, [From.GetFOA] [From.GetTitledFirstName]
To the deplorable,[Prev.GetFOA] [Prev.GetTitledFirstName], may your humours rot in your living body! I could never accept this injurious proposal.\n\n[From.GetFOA] [From.GetTitledFirstName]
Oh well, we could always make an Antipope.
We have already requested the the Pope to accept the Lateran Treaty but our requested was denied. Some time must pass before we try again.
We have already requested the Pope to accept the Lateran Treaty but our requested was denied. Some time must pass before we try again.
You haven't yet requested the Pope to accept the Lateran Treaty.

The Romans, after the glorious unification of the Italian Peninsula in a restored "Western Roman Empire" have convinced the Pope to join their Empire.\n\n[From.GetFOA] [From.GetTitledFirstName] and [FromFrom.GetFOA] [FromFrom.GetTitledFirstName] have signed a treaty in the Lateran Palace and after this they have jointly proclaimed that "The Roman Empire" is returning.
They really did this? The Pope meekly acquiesced to their demands?
Really? The Holy Roman Empire will be always The Roman Empire!
It is God's will that I, the Pope, rule the County of Rome and in particular the Bishopric of Rome.

[From.GetFOA] [From.GetTitledFirstName] has proclaimed that it is God's will that he, the Pope, rule the county of Rome. In the eyes of all Christian lords, this gives him and his successors a legitimate claim on Rome.

Our Commune has expanded far beyond the city of Rome, we now own enough land to be able to claim to be the the true inheritors of the Roman Republic. No longer are we confined to the city, now we can emulate the old Roman Republic, and take control of all Italy, and then Europe!

The Roman Republic has expanded far beyond the city of Rome, we now control all the Italian Peninsula and so we we can claim to be the the true inheritors of the Roman Empire in the West. There is still much work left ahead of us before we can reunite West and East, first and foremost the German must fall, but now we celebrate at the rebirth of Rome. Now is the time to conquer Europe!
The legions protected Rome for it's entire existence, and they have never been more needed than now. With the rebirth of Rome must come the rebirth of her legions.

The Roman legions were housed in the legion barracks. Our armies are now composed mainly of levies, but if we were to house them in a legion barracks, the strict organization within would provide an element of the legions of old.

The Roman legions were housed in the legion barracks. Our armies are now composed mainly of levies, but if we were to house them in a legion barracks, the strict organization within would provide an element of the legions of old.

The Roman legions were housed in the legion barracks. Our armies are now composed mainly of levies, but if we were to house them in a legion barracks, the strict organization within would provide an element of the legions of old.

The Roman legions were housed in the legion barracks. Our armies are now composed mainly of levies, but if we were to house them in a legion barracks, the strict organization within would provide an element of the legions of old.

The Roman Republic has returned! We are no longer confined to the city of Rome and fighting for our survival, we can claim our rightful place as the true inheritors of Rome. Although we do not yet even control the entire Italian Peninsula, the day will come when all the territories of old shall be recovered!

The Romans, after the conquest of a small strip of territory of
the Italian peninsula, have now the arrogance to declare that they have restored the Roman Republic and that, for this, they are the true heirs of
"The Roman Empire"!
If they will be not be stopped they could become really dangerous.
I hope to not have to regret that us have helped them!
That rump state the heir of Rome? The arrogance!
With our re-conquest of Italy, the entire world is forced to recognize that the Republic of Rome is back!
The Commune of Rome promised us their allegiance once they had won independence from the Pope, the time has come to remind them of that promise
On second though, let them enjoy their independence.

We are free from the Pope, but now we have another problem to deal with. We have recently received an emissary from the Holy Roman Empire requesting me to go and swear fealty to the Emperor. While it is true that we promised our allegiance to the Empire, promises can be forgotten...
We made a promise, and we shall keep it.

Friends, Romans, countrymen, lend me your ears! After the miraculous recovery of all the Italian peninsula the Western Roman Empire has been reborn! Italy has endured dark times since the imperial frontiers were stormed by barbarians and province after province burned at their touch, but now a bright new age has dawned for all of civilization.\n\n[Root.GetTitledFirstName] rules a restored Imperium Romanum Occidentalis, but much work remains to be done. There are still two illegimate Emperors that claim the mantle of Rome: one in the West and an other in the East and this is the time to deal with them. For the Senate and People of Rome!

The Romans have somehow managed to reclaim enough lost territory to declare the Western Roman Empire restored! It can no longer be denied that they are the true successors of Rome and its glorious legacy. They claim a new era is upon us.

column3: Est-ce que ça peut être vrai ?

column2: Really? The Holy Roman Empire will be always The Roman Empire!
Really? The Byzantines are the true Romans... not the Romans (?)

You are just entering the Senate when you notice that the Senators are crowding around you in a most... unusual fashion. Suddenly, before you can do anything, they all pull out daggers. There is no time to move, the senators engulf you, all shouting "Death to Tyrants."

There were three Praetura in Ancient Rome, the Praetor of the Army, who commanded the army in the field when the Consuls were indisposed, the Praetor Urbanus, who settled civil cases in Rome, and the Praetor Peregrinus, who settled civil cases among foreigners. Although all of those jobs are now taken care of by nobles, the office of Praetor is still very prestigious.

The office of the Quaestor oversaw the finances of the Roman Republic. They supervised the paying of the army and civil services, as well as ensuring the profit of the Empire. The armies are now levies, and the civil services are now staffed by nobles, so the title of Quaestor is mostly honorary.

The Roman Censor was originally entrusted with conducting the census, a great honour. However the duties of the office eventually extended to regulating public morality, i.e censoring documents which might displease the government or trouble the populace. The census no longer exists, and the populace isn't a problem, but the Censor is still very prestigious.

The tribune was the representative of the Plebeians in the government. They could veto and propose legislation, and convene the Senate. The position was jealously guarded by the Plebs, it was forbidden for a Patrician to be a tribune, and anyone who touched a tribune would have been torn apart by the mob. The Plebs don't have nearly as much say, however they still love their tribunes.

The Aediles were responsible for keeping up the maintenance of public buildings and for organizing festivals. It was one of the lower offices, but it was an excellent path towards success, giving the connections a young man needed to make it in the political world of Rome.

The Amphitheatre was the cultural center of the cities. Occasional performances went on there, but the real show was the gladiatoral combats. Gladiators fought there, and when they left often became auxiliaries of the legion. An amphitheatre also had the benefit of keeping the populace happy and entertained.

The Amphitheatre was the cultural center of the cities. Occasional performances went on there, but the real show was the gladiatoral combats. Gladiators fought there, and when they left often became auxiliaries of the legion. An amphitheatre also had the benefit of keeping the populace happy and entertained.

The Amphitheatre was the cultural center of the cities. Occasional performances went on there, but the real show was the gladiatoral combats. Gladiators fought there, and when they left often became auxiliaries of the legion. An amphitheatre also had the benefit of keeping the populace happy and entertained.

The Amphitheatre was the cultural center of the cities. Occasional performances went on there, but the real show was the gladiatoral combats. Gladiators fought there, and when they left often became auxiliaries of the legion. An amphitheatre also had the benefit of keeping the populace happy and entertained.

The Roman Baths were mainly used by the upper-class to relax, clean themselves, and talk. Our own upper-class will be happy to have such a place to relax, and our bath's will attract new knights to come fight for us and enjoy our luxuries.

The Roman Baths were mainly used by the upper-class to relax, clean themselves, and talk. Our own upper-class will be happy to have such a place to relax, and our bath's will attract new knights to come fight for us and enjoy our luxuries.

The Roman Baths were mainly used by the upper-class to relax, clean themselves, and talk. Our own upper-class will be happy to have such a place to relax, and our bath's will attract new knights to come fight for us and enjoy our luxuries.

The Roman Baths were mainly used by the upper-class to relax, clean themselves, and talk. Our own upper-class will be happy to have such a place to relax, and our bath's will attract new knights to come fight for us and enjoy our luxuries.

The forum is where the everyone comes to talk. Whether Pleb or Patrician, all can make there ideas heard in the public forum. Men meet, discuss, and debate all manner of things here, it is truly the center of any city!

The forum is where the everyone comes to talk. Whether Pleb or Patrician, all can make there ideas heard in the public forum. Men meet, discuss, and debate all manner of things here, it is truly the center of any city!

The forum is where the everyone comes to talk. Whether Pleb or Patrician, all can make there ideas heard in the public forum. Men meet, discuss, and debate all manner of things here, it is truly the center of any city!

The forum is where the everyone comes to talk. Whether Pleb or Patrician, all can make there ideas heard in the public forum. Men meet, discuss, and debate all manner of things here, it is truly the center of any city!

The legions of Rome were her backbone and the tool that made her great. What is Rome without her legions? We only have a small amount of territory left to us, but the Legion shall help us take more, and soon there will be many more.
With this tool we shall conquer our enemies!

Your son has recently come to you with the proposal that he join the Roman Legion. He argues that he will be serving the city and will bring great prestige. He will also be in great danger, but is it worth it?
No, leave the fighting to the Plebs

The doors open and a man in armor strides through. He has a deep scar running across his face, and his hand rests on his sword. Before your guards can do anything he runs up to you and... embraces you. With tears in his eyes the hardened warrior says "Father!" He has returned.

Today is the day you have long waited for, the day your son returns home. Suddenly he strides in with a smile on his face and a sword in his belt. He kneels at your feet, and greets you. Immediately after however he begins a critique of your defences, pointing out several problems and deficiencies in them.

Your son walks in, escorted by your guards. You move to greet him, when you notice something is wrong. Your son has a blank look on his face, and does not move on his own. A letter is attached to his breast, it reads "Your son fought heroically in several wars, yet his mind was not up to the rigours of battle, apologies, The Legion."

A bulky man carrying a sword walks casually into the room. Your bodyguards run up to disarm him, but they are sent sprawling. You run to the man and embrace him, your boy has been made a man by the Legion of Rome!

A courier is admitted into your throne room, wearing Legion Armour. Your worst suspicions are confirmed when he pulls out a note and begins to read "Dear Sir, We regret to inform you that your son has fallen in service to the Legion, Glory to Rome."

Your son arrives home from the legion today, you're sitting in your throne room, waiting, when the doors burst open. Expecting to see a young man in armour instead you see four slaves, each carrying a chest of gold. Your son follows them into the room. "I know looting is forbidden," he says "but I figure, that the enemies of Rome don't deserve to keep their gold."

You are eating in the mess hall when the message comes. "Your father has died, you have inherited his estates. A carriage will be provided to bring you to your father's court."Your comrades yell congratulations and condolences as you are escorted out of the room.
Every cloud has a silver lining.

It is desperate times for our nation. We are losing the war, and badly. We could always gather the gladiators into an organized fighting force. However they would only accept if we agreed to pay them, free them, and disband them when the war is over. The gladiators are numerous and fierce, yet we would lose much prestige in the eyes of others if we were forced to use slaves to fight, to say nothing of the expense...

The grand Colosseum of Rome! Others like it have been built, but none are as great as the original. It lay in ruins, used as a place for squatters to stay, but with the re-birth of Rome, it too is reborn!

The Colosseum has fallen into great disrepair since the old days of Rome. It is used by peasants without lords and all such manner of scoundrels as a refuge. If we were to re-build it to it's old glory, not only would we gain much prestige, but we also might be able to reinstate the old tradition of gladiators.

The Praetorian Guard was a formidable unit of elite soldiers that was used to protect the Emperor. If we were to re-create it, we could use the Praetorians as our shock troops, instead of just bodyguards.

The Praetorian Guard has returned! The best of the best, the most elite shock troops in the entire Roman Empire. They were usually used as bodyguards, but there is a fair amount of precedent for them to be used as troops as well. They shall trample our enemies underfoot.
This character is a gladiator, no longer free to hold titles or marry, they fight for glory and gold in the arena
This character was once a gladiator, but no longer fights, either due to age or injury.
This character has illegally kept the gladiator company active.
The Colosseum's recent renovation allows it to once more be flooded for naval battles.
The Colosseum has been rebuilt far beyond it's old glory, it can now house all of Rome!
The war has ended, and now according to the stipulations of our contract we should disband the gladiators as a military unit. However they are just slaves, and we could always just keep them...
Let's keep them, they're only slaves
The head of the Gladiators has just come to us and demanded we fulfil our word and free him and his men.
It is high time they went departed
The Colosseum has been fully rebuilt, and we can once again hold the great gladiator combats of old!
Sir here is your just due as my master.
That man needs the money more than I, send it back.
My lord, I humbly submit myself before you as a gladiator. I also humbly request that you provide me with the appropriate armour and weapons.

The reconstruction of the Colosseum has hit a serious snag. We don't know whether it was an accident of nature or sabotage, but much of our work has been undone. If we want to finish on schedule, then we'll have to go to considerable expense.
I guess we'll just have to try again.
The construction has of the Colosseum has been delayed.

Our advisers have informed us that they simply can't figure out how the Romans did it. It appears that much knowledge has been lost since the fall of the Empire, and we no longer have the know-how to build something like the Colosseum.

In ancient days, the Romans would use complex mechanisms to allow the Colosseum to be flooded, and naval battles would be fought within. It would be truly miraculous if we were to recreate this great feat, although there are no more battles upon the ocean as they existed.
Battles on water? Don't make me laugh.

The Colosseum is a great popular attraction, and is sure to draw many spectators. However it is up to us to determine how many can sit within, and how many will be forced to stand outside, straining to hear the exciting sounds.

The Colosseum was used as a refuge for all manner of dishonourable vagabond, and we are forced to expel them for our renovations. Now they have risen up in revolt, and drawn up into their cause thousands of the poor and dispossessed.
They shall fall beneath our Legions!
One of your gladiators has won a fight, and thus won you a sum of money. You could keep it, but the people would appreciate it if you distributed it amongst them.
Your gladiator has lost a fight, but has managed to keep his life. However you have lost money.
One of your gladiators has lost a fight, and so his life. But more importantly he has lost you a substantial sum of money!

A merchant approaches you with three huge men in tow. He says that they're from the land Ethiopia, and fight more viciously than it is thought possible, and he is willing to sell you one for the Colosseum.
Give me the cheapest on you have.
I'll take that one in the middle.
To buy and sell a man is a sin.

One man is lying in the dust of the arena, his eyes wide and fearful. The other man is pointing a sword at his neck. They both look to you for instructions as to what to do next, will the man live, or die?

Gladiators from all over the empire have come together to fight against us. It started at a training school in the old city of Capua, and has since spread like wildfire across the entire nation. The gladiators demand equal treatment and a return home, and are willing to fight for it.
You are reclining at the arena when a slightly seedy looking man sidles up to you, and whispers "Wanna place a bet on the big game? I take all bets, no questions asked."

You are watching the gladiators train, when suddenly you are hit with the urge to go down to the ring and fight with them. It may be undignified and dangerous, but sometimes a man finds that he must prove himself to the world, whether he is an emperor or a gladiator.
The day's training has served you well. You left practically unscathed, and are now a much better fighter.
I should do this every day!
The Gladiators here have risen in revolt, attracting not just their fellows but all manner of discontented servants.
You go down to the arena

While excavating parts of the Colosseum, one team of labourers has come across a locked chest, undoubtedly hid by some frightened, long dead Roman nobleman shortly before the fall of the city. Inside there is a treasure trove of golden coins and other such valuable artefacts, all worth a pretty penny indeed.
At least the Goths didn't get them...

The foreman for the renovation of the Colosseum just entered the throne room. He says that while his men were working on the construction, they came across a cache of ancient Roman artefacts. There all sort of things in there, from swords and spears to chalices and paintings. Putting them on display in the throne room will really help our claim of being the inheritor of Rome.
The swords will look wonderful over there...

While the men were digging new foundations, they came across a small buried room. Upon entering, it became evident that it was a chapel. On the altar, there is a stack of ancient bibles, with beautiful drawings. They also contain previously unkonwn stories from the lives of the saints, some of them using first-hand sources! We should send them to the Pope as a gesture of goodwill.
